platforms.message: MediaLibrary.framework will be removed in a future OS version. Use Photos.framework or iTunesLibrary.framework instead.
platforms.name: macOS

abstract.text: Access read-only collections of the user’s multimedia content.
An identifier for the media group’s type.
The
class provides an interface for accessing a collection of media objects from various sources. It serves as the initial access point of the Media Library framework.
Initializes the media library based on the specified load options.
Specifies one or more relative paths inside the caller’s app bundle in which to search for media files. The value for this key is an array of strings (relative paths inside the caller’s app bundle).
Identifies the folder containing audio loops from Apple.
Defines which media sources to exclude when loading. This option is processed after
. The value for this key is an array of strings (media source identifiers). For a list of valid media source identifiers, see

Specifies the well-known folders that should be searched for media files. If this key is not present, none of the well-known folders will be provided. The value for this key is an array of strings (identifiers that correspond to well-known folder locations). For a list of well-known folder identifiers, see
Defines which media sources to include when loading. If not present, load all available media sources. This option is processed after
. If
is present but

is not, then only those sources specified here will be loaded. This is useful for loading a single media source. When both keys are present, this is useful for adding one or more media sources that normally would not appear for the requested library type. The value for this key is an array of strings (media source identifiers). For a list of valid media source identifiers, see
Identifies the user’s Movies folder.
Defines which sources to load based on library type. If not present, this will load all sources. The value for this key is a media source type. For a list of valid media source types, see
The media source providing content from Aperture.
The media source for app-defined folders. This identifies a media source created from a relative path inside the caller’s app bundle. This source provides data when
is provided in the options.
The media source for custom folders. Currently, the only custom folder is the folder containing audio loops from Apple. This source provides data when
is provided with the
value.
Specifies the source type associated with a particular media source. Source type reflects the primary type of media within the source. These constants are used to specify values for
in the
method of
Audio source type. Includes iTunes, GarageBand, and Logic.
Image source type. Includes iPhoto, Aperture, and Photo Booth.
Movie source type. Includes iMovie and Final Cut Pro.
Identifiers for media group types in the Aperture media source. These constants are used to specify a media group’s
attribute.
Identifiers for media group types in the Final Cut Pro media source. These constants are used to specify a media group’s
attribute.

doc://com.apple.medialibrary/documentati.title: Final Cut Pro Media Group Type Identifiers

abstract.text: Identifiers for media group types in folder-based media sources. These constants are used to specify a media group’s
attribute.
Identifiers for media group types in the GarageBand media source. These constants are used to specify a media group’s
attribute.
Identifiers for media group types in the Logic media source. These constants are used to specify a media group’s
attribute.
Identifiers for media sources which correspond to apps used to manage groups of media objects. Used with
Identifiers for well-known media folders used to specify the value for
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type that can be converted to and from an associated raw value.
A type that provides mathematical set operations.
A type that can be initialized using an array literal.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
A type that presents a mathematical set interface to a bit set.
